case_name: The Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindustan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd.

facts.text: On 13 December 1961, Inspectors Uma Shankar and Bisuddha Nand Jha and Constable Bishan Singh of Central Excise Department were on checking patrol duty on 330 Down Barauni passenger train from Barharwa to Pakur in Santhal Parganas, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: On 13 December, 1961, Inspectors Uma Shankar and Bisuddha Nand Jha and Constable Bishan Singh, all belonging to the Central Excise Department were on checking patrol duty on 330 Down Barauni passenger train proceeding from Barharwa to Pakur which are Railway Stations in Santhal Parganas in Bihar.

facts.text: Appellant Nazir Mian was travelling by the Barauni passenger train and found in the latrine of a compartment with two bags of cloves weighing about 2 pounds 10 seers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Nazir Mian was travelling by Barauni passenger train. When the train stopped at Pakur the excise staff found Nazir Mian in the latrine of one of the compartments of the train with two bags of cloves weighing about 2 pounds 10 seers.

facts.text: Inspector Uma Shankar disclosed identity, asked if duty paid on cloves, Nazir Mian said no, then seized bags and arrested him.

anchor.surface_text: The door of the latrine was closed. Inspector Uma Shankar pushed the door when it was opened from inside. Uma Shankar disclosed his identity and asked if duty had been paid for the cloves. Nazir Mian answered in -the negative.

facts.text: Train started while arrest, stopped at level crossing after alarm chain pulled, excise staff got down with Nazir Mian and bags.

anchor.surface_text: Inspector Uma Shankar thereupon seized the bags and arrested Nazir Mian. While this was being done, the train started. Shortly after the train had started it stopped at a level crossing in consequence of one of the persons of the excise staff pulling the alarm chain.

facts.text: Nazir Mian rescued by other appellants Ram Kirpal Bhagat and Ganga Dayal Shah, bags taken away, scuffle injured inspectors.

anchor.surface_text: The excise staff got down,with Nazir Mian. The two bags of cloves were also brought down. Certain persons collected on the spot. Nazir Mian is alleged to have been rescued by other appellants and the bags of cloves were taken away.

facts.text: Appellants Nazir Mian, Ram Kirpal Bhagat, Ganga Dayal Shah and others charged under IPC sections 147,149,333,379,332,225.

anchor.surface_text: In the scuffle that ensued, one of the Inspectors received simple injuries and the other a grievous injury. The three appellants Nazir Mian, Ram Kirpal Bhagat and Ganga Dayal Shah and two other persons Jhaman Mian and Raghunath Prasad Yadav were all charged under section 147, 149, 333 and 379 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Nazir Mian charged under Land Customs Act s.7, Sea Customs Act s.167/19, Imports Exports Control Act s.5/Import Control Order.

anchor.surface_text: Nazir Mian was also charged under section 7 of the Land Customs Act, 1924 for contravention of section 5 of the, said Act and also under section 167 item 81 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 for contravention of Section 19 of the said Act and also under section 5 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947

facts.text: Trial before Assistant Sessions Judge, Dumka: Raghunath acquitted, appellants and Jhaman convicted under various IPC sections, Nazir acquitted of customs charges due to no complaint.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial before the Assistant Sessions Judge, Dumka in Santhal Parganas, Raghunath Prasad Yadav was acquitted of all the charges and the appellants Nazir Mian, Ram Kirpal Bhagat and Ganga Dayal Shah along with Jhaman Mian were all convicted under sections 147 and 332 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sentences to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: The said four accused including the three appellants were sentenced to several terms of imprisonment and the said sentences were ordered to run concurrently.

facts.text: Appeal to Patna High Court, Criminal Appeal No. 210 of 1966, judgment dated January 31, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the-judgment and order dated January 31, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 210 of 1966.

facts.text: High Court held Sea Customs Act and Imports Exports Control Act apply to Santhal Parganas, inspectors had authority, burden on Nazir under s.178A, convictions upheld except some sentences set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the Sea Customs Act, 1878 and the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 applied to the Santhal Parganas with the result that the import of cloves was prohibited duty was payable on cloves the Inspectors were officers of Customs

facts.text: Supreme Court Criminal Appeal No. 182 of 1966 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 182 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the-judgment and order dated January 31, 1966 of the Patna High Court

facts.text: Santhal Parganas are Scheduled Areas under Art. 244 and Fifth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The Santhal Parganas are included in the Scheduled.Areas dealt with in Art. 244 and the Fifth Schedule to the Constitution. Paragraph 5 in the Fifth Schedule deals with laws applicable to Scheduled Areas.

facts.text: Bihar Regulation I of 1951 made by Governor under para 5(2) Fifth Schedule applies Imports and Exports Control Act 1947 to Santhal Parganas, held valid.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Regulation I of 1951 is a valid piece of legislation emanating from the legislative authority of the Governor in its plenitude of power.

facts.text: Import of cloves prohibited under Imports Control Order 1955 under Imports Exports Control Act 1947 s.3.

anchor.surface_text: The import of cloves was prohibited under the Imports Control Order 1955 made under s. - 3 of the Imports Exports Control Order 1947.

facts.text: Cloves are dutiable goods under Indian Tariff Act 1934, applicable to Santhal Parganas via Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation 1872 schedule.

anchor.surface_text: They were also dutiable goods under the Indian Tariff Act, 1934 which was applicable to the Santhal Parganas being one of the Acts mentioned in the Schedule to the Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation, 1872.

facts.text: Inspectors of Central Excise were Land Customs Officers and Officers of Customs via notifications No. 6 Cus. 28 Sep 1951 under Sea Customs s.6 and CBR Notif 1 Cus. 25 Jan 1958 amended May 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless by virtue of notification No. 6 Cus. dated 28th September, 1951 under section 6 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 and notification No. CBR Notification 1. Cus. dated 25th January, 1958  as amended in May, 1958  the two Inspectors in the present case had authority

facts.text: Circumstances: Nazir had 2 bags cloves no duty paid, concealed in train latrine, Pakur 11-12 miles from East Pakistan border, cloves not grown in India - reasonable suspicion for arrest u/s 173 Sea Customs.

anchor.surface_text: The-evidence in the present case established the following facts. First, the appellant Nazir Mian had in possession two bags of cloves and noduty was paid on those cloves. Secondly the said appellant kept the cloves in two bags and concealed the same in the latrine of the railways compartment.

facts.text: Land Customs Act 1924 not applicable as existing law to Santhal Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: The Land Customs Act, 1924 was not applicable to the Santha. Parganas as an existing law within the meaning of Art. 372 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Sea Customs Act 1878 applies to Santhal Parganas via Imports Exports Control Act 1947 s.3(2) deeming prohibited goods under s.19, all provisions apply.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the Sea Customs Act, 1878 and the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 applied to the Santhal Parganas

facts.text: No special notification under s.178A Sea Customs for cloves, but unnecessary as goods removed by accused.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of special notification under s, 178A of the Sea Customs Act. 1878 specifying goods to which the section applies, the onus of proof under that section cannot be placed on persons whose goods are seized

facts.text: Pakur is 11-12 miles from East Pakistan border.

anchor.surface_text: Fourthly, the place o f occurrence was at a distance of only 11 12 miles from the East Pakistan border.

facts.text: Cloves not grown in India.

anchor.surface_text: Fifthly, cloves are not grown in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(2) deems prohibited goods under Imports Act as prohibited u/s.19 Sea Customs, and 'all provisions of that Act shall have effect accordingly'; distinguished appellant's narrow reading using textual interpretation and Madras Customs precedent.

holdings.text: The Bihar Regulation I of 1951 is a valid piece of legislation made by the Governor under para 5(2) of the Fifth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Regulation I of 1951 is a valid piece of legislation emanating from the legislative authority of the Governor in its plenitude of power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governor's power for peace and good government includes plenary legislative authority to apply laws to Scheduled Areas, analogous to s.92 Govt of India Act 1935; not delegated or conditional legislation.

holdings.text: The Land Customs Act, 1924 was not applicable to the Santhal Parganas as an existing law under Art. 372(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Land Customs Act, 1924 was not applicable to the Santha. Parganas as an existing law within the meaning of Art. 372 1  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Existing laws from non-Scheduled Areas do not automatically extend to Scheduled Areas; requires specific application under Fifth Schedule para 5.

holdings.text: Central Excise Inspectors Uma Shankar and Bisuddha Nand Jha were Officers of Customs with authority to arrest and seize under Sea Customs ss.173 and 178.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless by virtue of notification No. 6 Cus. dated 28th September, 1951 under section 6 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 and notification No. CBR Notification 1. Cus. dated 25th January, 1958  as amended in May, 1958  the two Inspectors

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notifications under Sea Customs s.6 appoint Land Customs Officers (including Central Excise Inspectors via Land Customs notification) as Customs Officers.

holdings.text: There was reasonable suspicion justifying arrest of Nazir Mian under s.173 Sea Customs Act based on circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The-evidence in the present case established the following facts. First, the appellant Nazir Mian had in possession two bags of cloves and noduty was paid on those cloves. Secondly the said appellant kept the cloves in two bags and concealed the same

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession of undutied prohibited cloves concealed in train latrine, near East Pakistan border (11-12 miles), cloves not grown in India constitute reasonable suspicion.

holdings.text: Cloves are prohibited goods under Imports Control Order 1955 and dutiable under Indian Tariff Act 1934 applicable to Santhal Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: The import of cloves was prohibited under the Imports Control Order 1955 made under s. - 3 of the Imports Exports Control Order 1947. They were also dutiable goods under the Indian Tariff Act, 1934 which was applicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Import Control Order and Tariff Act listed in Santhal Parganas Settlement Regulation 1872 schedule.

holdings.text: Section 178A Sea Customs does not shift burden of proof absent special notification specifying the goods; unnecessary here as goods removed by accused.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of special notification under s, 178A of the Sea Customs Act. 1878 specifying goods to which the section applies, the onus of proof under that section cannot be placed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict textual requirement for special notification to invoke reverse onus; moot point due to removal of seized goods.

holdings.text: Inspectors were public servants acting in discharge of official duties, rendering IPC convictions under ss.147, 332 etc. valid.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants Nazir Mian, Ram Kirpal Bhagat and Ganga Dayal Shah and two other persons Jhaman Mian and Raghunath Prasad Yadav were all charged under section 147, 149, 333 and 379 of the Indian Penal Code

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arrest and seizure lawful under Sea Customs, so resistance/rescue constitutes offences against public servants.
